abstract: Jason Baldwin, Damien Echols and Jessie Misskelley Jr., who in August were freed from prison after nearly 20 years, are expected at a premiere screening of "Paradise Lost 3: Purgatory," the latest entry in a documentary series that has chronicled their case.
snippet: Jason Baldwin, Damien Echols and Jessie Misskelley Jr., who in August were freed from prison after nearly 20 years, are expected at a premiere screening of "Paradise Lost 3: Purgatory," the latest entry in a documentary series that has chronicled...
lead_paragraph: After gaining their freedom following a nearly two-decade ordeal, the Arkansas men known as the West Memphis Three are planning to attend a premiere screening in New York for the latest entry in a documentary series that has helped keep their case in the public eye for more than 15 years. The three men, Jason Baldwin, Damien Echols and Jessie Misskelley Jr., who were freed from prison in August after having been convicted in 1994 of the murders of three 8-year-old boys, are expected to be at the New York Film Festival on Monday evening for a screening of the film "Paradise Lost 3: Purgatory," a non-fiction feature directed by Joe Berlinger and Bruce Sinofsky, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said.

headline.main: West Memphis Three Will Attend New York Film Festival
